objects.comment: Comet Holmes reached naked-eye brightness in 2007 after some amazing outbursts.  It is the fuzzy object just left of the bright stars of Perseus.

Comet Holmes in Perseus
Comet Holmes reached naked-eye brightness in 2007 after some amazing outbursts. It is the fuzzy object just left of the bright stars of Perseus.

objects.photodata:
Title Comet Holmes in Perseus

Description Comet Holmes reached naked-eye brightness in 2007 after some amazing outbursts. It is the fuzzy object just left of the bright stars of Perseus.

Original Date 11/1/07, 8:45 AM

Make Canon

Camera Canon EOS DIGITAL REBEL XT

Focal Length (35mm) 66mm

Metering Mode Partial

ISO Equivalent 800

Exposure Time 20.0s

Aperture ƒ/11.0

Exposure bias 0 EV

Exposure Program Manual control

White balance Auto white balance

Flash Flash did not fire

Resolution 804 x 836

objects.comment: Comet Holmes underwent an outburst in 2012 that made it visible to the naked-eye.  This image was taken with a Canon Digital Rebel XT on the 12" Meade with a focal reducer that caused star flaring/blurriness.  Apparently tracking was off, hence trailing.

objects.comment: Comet C/2011 L4 PanSTARRS in 3/14/13 taken with the Canon Digital Rebel with its kit lens on a tripod.  This comet was barely visible to the naked eye. The comet's tail points roughly upwards and away from the Sun (which is the norm).

objects.comment: A short movie of Comet C/2017 O1 (ASASSN) moving through the sky, in black and white. It is the faint object, which appears to be moving quickly, but this is due to the framerate of the video. Taken with Atik on 10/17/17, at about magnitude 8.5.

objects.comment: Comet C/2020 F3 (NEOWISE) on 7/17/20.  Taken with the Canon T5i (30 sec exposure) on a tripod in the backyard.  Even though it was low in the WNW, this was one of the brightest, easiest to see comets in decades. It reached 2nd magnitude and sported separate gas and dust tails.
objects.creator: JCP
objects.imageCaption:
Comet C/2020 F3 (NEOWISE)
Comet C/2020 F3 (NEOWISE) on 7/17/20. Taken with the Canon T5i (30 sec exposure) on a tripod in the backyard. Even though it was low in the WNW, this was one of the brightest, easiest to see comets in decades. It reached 2nd magnitude and sported separate gas and dust tails.

objects.photodata:

objects.comment: Comet C/2020 F3 (NEOWISE) seen setting over the ONU Observatory roof on 7/18/20.  A 90 sec exposure with the Canon T5i.  The green tint of the comet's coma differs from the pale yellow dust tail.  The blue gas tail was to the left of the dust tail, but does not show up here.
objects.creator: JCP
objects.imageCaption:
